1.text: Against Ptolemy? Cosmography in Early Kalam

1.label: text
1.text: This article explores how mulakallimiin engaged with competing visions of the cosmos—traditionalist and Aristotelian-Ptolemaic—to the beginning of the sixth/ twelfth century. Drawing on works of kaldm, Quran commentary, and items from other genres, I demonstrate that rationalist theologians remained divided on such questions as the shape of the earth tothe end ofthis period. These disagreements, ‘moreover, cannot be explained in terms of school affiliation. Based on a compre- hensive examination of published sources, I argue that cosmographical opinion among mutakallimiin was a function of exposure to late ancient learning, intellee- ‘ual formation, and personal inclination more than doctrinal commitment.

3.text: For the purposes of this article, the Aristotelian-Ptolemaic cosmography is the view that the earth is an immobile sphere, nestled in the center of a series of concentric celestial orbs or shells. The precise number of orbs or shells, and the exact nature of their interaction, along with much else, was the subject of considerable disagreement among Aristotle and Ptolemy's interpreters and interlocutors in later centuries, Muslim or otherwise. !3 Notwith- standing their divergences, however, they “were in agreement with regard to the sphericity of the Earth and its position at the center of the universe, as well as the sphericity and the circular motion of the heavens.” " These fundamental features of the Aristotelian-Ptolemaic paradigm remained stable down to modernity, '$ and for this reason I choose to present them as a single model or paradigm,

3.label: text
3.text: This cosmography espoused by Muslim advocates of ‘iim al-nujim in the period surveyed is the alternative against which traditionalists defined themselves, as shall become clear. The traditionalist cosmography, to which I devote a separate section below, consists of belief in a flat earth, beneath which are a further six earths. Instead of the celestial spheres of the Aristotelian-Ptolemaic cosmography, there is a series of seven heavens (either domed or vaulted), above which is God’s throne (‘arsh). What lies beneath the seventh and lowermost arth was, in the traditionalist corpus, subject to considerable disagreement. Nonetheless, the basic features of the traditionalist cosmography permit one to refer to it as a single model, or paradigm, since it remains remarkably stable.

4.text: I begin with a brief survey of quranic cosmography. I then proceed to explore traditional- ist doctrine, and whether and to what extent it represents a departure from the vision of the cosmos presented in the Quran, I also attempt a characterization of traditionalist attitudes toward rival nontraditionalist viewpoints. These are necessary contexts for the study of the cosmography of the mutakallimiin, representing the standard against which they reacted. Their discussions show evidence of extensive engagement with cosmographical traditional- ism, sometimes by way of critique and at other times of adherence, in preference to the Greek alternatives. I then address the cosmographical views of individual rationalist theologians whose works are extant or whose opinions are preserved in later sources in more or less chronological order. This discussion forms the bulk of the paper.

11.label: text
11.text: Muslim awareness of the Aristotelian-Ptolemaic cosmography predates the apogee of the Translation Movement by several decades. The earliest opinions on the subject from ‘mutakallimiin, preserved in later doxographies and other sources, already reflect familiarity with Aristotle, as noted by Josef van Ess.” Hishdm b. al-Hakam (d. 179/79Sf.), a disciple of the Shifi Imam Ja‘far al-Sadiq (d. 148/765), played the leading role in introducing cosmo- graphical questions to kalaim; his lead was followed by younger contemporaries, including Abi al-Hudhayl al-‘Allaf (d. 226/840f.) and al-Nazzam (d. 220/835 or 230/845).75 Though it is not clear precisely when the distinction between the “subtleties” (dagig, also lati, ghamid) and “main topics” (Jali!) of kalam emerged, cosmography belonged firmly to the former domain and generated disagreement from the outset. > Cosmography was a standard feature of the discourse of the mutakallimiin, and the main lines of inquiry were already well estab- lished, before they received focused elaboration at the hands of theological systematizers toward the end of the third/ninth century. Cosmographical discussion in this period occurs in the context of questions of bodies, motion, and void (ie., physics) and, to a lesser extent, in the refutation of other religions. On all of these issues, dialogue and polemical exchange with non-Muslims seem to have been the main driver of opinion. 12.text: As the first theologian known to have entertained views on Greek cosmography, Hisham b. al-Hakam’s profile emerges with the faintest of clarity in the sources. He is reported to have refuted the opinion that the earth extends infinitely in all directions, which Aristotle attributes (with some variation) to Xenophanes of Colophon.” The earth’s suspension in place raised important theological questions about God’s role in the maintenance of the cos- ‘mos, hence the sustained interest of mutakallimiin in the subject. Hisham is claimed to have taught that the earth rests on a body with a tendency to ascend (jism sad), which counter- acts the earth’s tendency to fall, thus keeping the latter in place. ”* By seeking a rationalistic explanation for the earth’s suspension, as opposed to assuming it rests (e.g.) on the back of a cosmic fish, Hisham implicitly rejects the traditionalist cosmography. There is, however, no hint in the sources as to his views on the shape of the earth. Hisham is also reported to have persuaded a Zoroastrian priest (mibadh) that there is nothing beyond the (finite) cosmos, i.e,, that we would not be able to see anything or extend an outstretched hand beyond its bor- ders.” We also know that he was associated with corporealism, famously advocating God as the possessor of “a body unlike bodies,” located above the throne. It is not clear, however, ‘what bearing this had on his views on more strictly cosmographical questions.

13.text: Collectively, the theological triumvirs Hisham, Abii al-Hudhayl, and al-Nazzim broached some of the major cosmographical issues that would preoccupy subsequent generations of ‘mutakallimiin. Most prominently, they entertained opinions on the cause of the earth’s immo- bility and on the finitude of the cosmos, usually in opposition to various non-Muslim groups. None is known to have addressed the earth’s shape, or to have explicitly engaged with the traditionalist cosmography, however. In the case of al-Nazzim, this may be a result of his extreme scepticism toward hadith and other transmitted material, which he may have felt were beneath his attention. With respect to Abii al-Hudhayl and Hisham, the possible rea- sons for this apparent lack of engagement with traditionalism are less straightforward. The absence may be simply a function of the paucity of source material.% Nevertheless, with these foundations, the basis for more systematic exploration of cosmography in kaldim was laid.

Misi al-Nawbakhtt (4. bet. 300/912 and 310/922) is known to have “adopted several theses of the Mu‘tazilf theological school.” Unlike al-RassT and al-Hadi ila al-Hagq, however, he enjoyed privileged access to the cosmographical knowledge of late antiquity through his residence in Baghdad and his association “with a group of translators of Greek philosophical works.”!°! His views on astronomy and astrology have been carefully reconstructed by Wilferd Madelung based on later texts. " Because the relevant work has already been done, I shall mention only a few of the most pertinent cosmographical points. Al-Nawbakhtt is known to have written against ‘Abii ‘AIT al-Jubba’’s critique of the science of the stars.'° Notwithstanding this, however, al-Nawbakhif was decidedly opposed to Aristotle, the pagans of Harrn, and other exponents of that branch of learning. He produced an early account of the divergent views on the sub- ject among Muslims and non-Muslims that demonstrates extensive firsthand knowledge, including of Aristotle’s De Caelo and its commentaries. ! Al-Nawbakhti is not always con- sistent in naming some of the mutakallimiin associated with particular cosmographical opin- ions. 1° He ascribes the opinion that the earth rests “on the back of a fish [. ..] on the horn of a bull [.. .] standing on the ground (hara)” to a group among the proto-Sunnis (qawm min ahl al-hadith), without commenting on it." Like Abi al-Hudhayl, al-Nawbakhtl refutes the perpetual downward fall of the earth by appealing to the example of an object dropped to the ground (a feather or a clod of mud). Notwithstanding his very extensive exposure to late ancient knowledge, however, he remained “in outlook a Muslim kaldm theologian, not a phi- losopher,” and shared “the basic rationalist principles of the Mu‘tazila.” 8 His wide-ranging criticisms of the astronomers and astrologers (Madelung’s translations of munajjimiin and ashab al-ahkam respectively) was to prove a valuable source for later theologians of dispa- rate tendencies, including the idiosyncratic Hanbali Ibn al-Jawzi (d. 597/1201).!°

18.text: In the course of the period, quranic hermeneutics came to figure prominently in kalm discussions of cosmography, perhaps for the first time. Most of the relevant material is found not in works of theology proper, but in Quran commentaries authored by mutakallimiin. The rationalist theologians seem to have turned to authoring full-length works of afsir late in the third/ninth century, which forced them to confront cosmographical questions that might otherwise have eluded them. A number of key quranic verses emerged as the focal points for discussion (appendix 1).

18.label: text
18.text: The trends witnessed in the work of Abi ‘AIT al-Jubba’T and al-Ka‘bi, the chiefS of the Basran and Baghdad Mu‘tazilis, continued into the next period of cosmographical discus- sion in kaldm, which is marked by considerable continuity but is also notable for its depar- tures. The major development is the theological careers of Abii al-Hasan al-Ash‘ari and Abi Mansir al-Maturidf. Neither seems to have been especially important during his lifetime, and ‘one cannot speak of Ash‘ari or Maturidi “schools” until well after their deaths. "3! Neverthe- less, with their advent one can retrospectively speak of the beginnings of what would become classical Sunni theology, with all that this entails for cosmographical doctrine.

21.text: Thus, by the early fourtlvtenth century, key patterns of cosmographical thinking (in the context of schools of kaldm) had emerged that would have a decisive bearing on subsequent developments. Following his conversion, al-Ash‘ari committed himself to occasionalism— which would endure as a distinctive feature of Ash‘ari theology—while retaining an interest in the kalam questions and methods of his Mu‘tazili teachers, including those pertaining to cosmography. Al-Maturidi’s vision of the cosmos was, on the other hand, much more closely related to that of al-Tabari than to that of the Mu‘tazila, and he was not exercised by the same set of questions. Even among the Mu‘tazilis, formative exposure to the traditionalist disciplines (most importantly, hadith) could produce a corresponding inclination, as we have seen with Ibn al-Ikhshid, Overall, among these three theologians of clearly divergent view- points, theological affiliation is not an accurate index of cosmographical opinion. Similar conclusions may apply outside the Muslim community for this period: the Jewish mutakal- lim Dawiid al-Mugammas (d. ca. 325/937), whom most scholars regard to have been deeply influenced by the Mu‘tazilis, claims that the earth is discoid and the sky dome-shaped, in ‘good Talmudic fashion.
